The Students' Fate
Lies In The Stars
BY DOUG FELLMAN

On-Campus Social Life:
The Drinking Age Dilemma
Maryland's new drinking law, which
raises the legal age for purchasing beer and
wine from 18 to 21, promises to profoundly affect the social life of Hopkins students
as well as the campus social atmosphere. The
new regulations went into effect last July.
Anyone under the age of 18 as of July 1, will
have to wait until his twenty-first birthday
in order to legally purchase beer or wine in
Maryland. Because approximately one-half
of this year's freshman class is affected by
the new law, the consequences of the raised
drinking age are already being felt at
Hopkins.
Freshman orientation was the first campus activity that forced students to grapple
with the new problem. Whereas beer has
been one of the main attractions of previous
orientation parties, this year's activities were
dry. Orientation organizers, a combination
of students and administrators, realized that
serving liquor to only one half of the
freshmen would have severely alienated fifty percent of the class, destroying the principles behind orientation. Furthermore, no
student was willing to sign his name to a liquor license fearing repurcussions in the
event that some underage freshmen were able
to get ahold of liquor. Orientation organizers
were stuck with one option; eliminate beer.
Orientation was the first but certainly not
the last student activity that will be affected
by the new drinking law. Fraternity and class
sponsored parties will invariably run into
similar problems over the next several years.
Serving liquor while strictly enforcing the
law will result in the alienation of the nondrinking population. Eliminating liquor

from campus events will encourage students
who can drink to search for off-campus
entertainment. Regardless of what decision
is made, campus social life will suffer.
The new drinking law offers few benefits
for Hopkins. The law was never directed at
college students. It was designed as an indirect effort to combat the drunk driving
problem. Ironically, its effect at Hopkins will
be to encourage drinking and driving as
students may end up traveling great distances
in search of bars that will serve them. The
new law, therefore, poses safety problems
for Hopkins students by pushing them off
campus.
These problems can only be avoided if
the Baltimore City police choose not to enforce this law here at Hopkins. This is not
a ludicrous proposition. At man'y other colleges in areas where the drinking age is above
18, local police ignore student abuses of
drinking laws as long as the violations occur on campus. It is likely that the Baltimore
police will have no interest in enforcing the
new drinking law at JHU. In the past, police
have been reluctant to deal with certain illegal activities occuring on the Homewood
campus. Perhaps the only way we will know
if we can in fact get away with seving liquor
to all students, is by trying it first. Perhaps
we will never try it given the understandable
reluctance of students to sign a liquor license
and accept the possible consequences. It
seems, however, that continued allegiance to
the law can only have a detrimental effect
on the social life of the campus and the safety of students.

The Possible Problems
Of Dean Reorganization
The success of the recent reorganization
of the Homewood Dean's office will remain
unknown for several months. Although the
new system has already been in effect since
July, the new Deans are still trying to get a
firm understanding of their roles and duties.
The precise implications of the reorganization are not yet clear, however, there are certain possible problems worth watching out
for.
Firstly, Norman Krueger, Associate
Dean of Administration brings to his new
job more experience in finance than
academics. There is the chance that Krueger
may stress financial considerations over
those of' the students. This conflict may have
serious implications in areas such as Admissions which Krueger now controls.
Secondly, Lucien Brush, Associate Dean
of Undergraduate and Graduate Studies, is
a member of the Engineering School. Over
the next decade it will likely be the Arts and
Sciences Division that will experience the
greatest troubles and will need important administrators going to bat for it. Perhaps
Dean Brush will be less likely to do this than

someone with stronger ties to the Arts and
Sciences division.
Thirdly, there is the question of whether
the new deans will be attentive to student
concerns. Essential to this is the dean's use
of Chris Colombo, Assistant Dean of
Students. As Colombo, who works closely
with student groups, has a clear understanding of students' attitudes, the new deans
must utilize him as an information source
and policy advisor. Colombo previously had
a very close relationship with the recently
departed Dean of Academic Services, Jakie
Hall. Whether Brush and Kruger will utilize
Colombo to the same extent remains to be
seen. If they do not it will be detrimental to
students.
The new administrative reorganization of
the Dean's Office may turn out quite well
as far as students and the University in
general are concerned. The News-Letter certainly hopes it will. Yet the seeds of certain
problems are apparent and care should be
taken by both the administration and the
students to see that the seeds do not grow
into weeds.

A new administrative structure, which on paper resembles
a Christmas tree with two stars
at the top, is now in place and
governing on the Homewood
campus. One of the top stars,
Dean Sigmund Suskind, readi- •
ly admits that the organization
is unique. Indeed it is, and as
the academic year gets under-.
way, the eyes of undergraduate
and graduate students, faculty,
and University administrators
who find campus politics interesting and/or fun will be
watching the new system quite
closely.
On paper, the reorganization
is complex. In reality it is even
more so. Clearly it is in the best
interest of both the students
and the institution, that the
design work. The deans, of
which there are many at different ranks and with different
personalities
and
are
of
temperaments,
unanimous mind in one respect:
they sincerely want the schools
of Arts and Sciences and
Engineering to run smoothly,
efficiently, and with excellence.
In this era of instant analysis,
when a President's televised address is critiqued within minutes
by reporters, pundits, and
politicians of the opposing party, it is tempting to draw conclusions quickly. Yet when
dealing with something as close
to home as Homewood's new
administrative structure, we
must strive above all else to be
fair. With the new administration, in office just nine weeks
and only now facing its first
real test as students return and
the semester gets underway,
fairness dictates time. We owe
the deans that much, and a
good faith effort must be made
on both sides. This does not
mean that concerns won't be
voiced or problems discussed;
there are concerns and there are
potential problems. Rather, I
hope, such issues can be dealt
with honestly, and in a mature
way.
Students on this campus have
long been calling out for a
tighter, more collegiate atmosphere at Homewood. It is
interesting to note that one of
the reasons the new organization was structured as it now
stands was to take administration of this division of the

University out of Garland Hall
and to permit it to operate independently, as a single unit. If
indeed Homewood can operate
as such, why can it not devote
its attention to the primary purpose of its existence: students.
Let it be said here and now,
and let it be said often, that
Homewood campus can devote
more attention and time to
undergraduates without losing
a bit of its reputation as a major research university. And I
would argue that such attention
would even enhance the reputation this place already has.
The administrative organization which oversees this campus
needs to pay as much attention
to students as it does to faculty. This tends to put the deans
in a difficult situation because
the average undergraduate's
tenure here is four years while
the average faculty member's
tenure is a lifetime. But such
conflict is inherent in the institution of the deanship, and
while the tug by the faculty may
be mighty, that of the student's
is equally important.
Students need to meet the
deans and talk to the deans.
And they need to do so often—
as the rule rather than the.exception. The deans need to be
seen. We—and here I mean all
students, in leadership positions
or not—need to tell them exactly what's on our minds. The
deans, in turn, should be
responsive to our problems
when they can be, and open to
new ideas which may also go
against initial hesitations.
Sometimes the concerns of
undergraduates will not be the
concerns of the administration.
Sometimes undergraduates will
want to deal with issues the administration would rather leave
alone.
It will be in dealing with these
sometimes sensitive issues that
the new structure will prove its
true worth to undergraduates.
Hanging on the wall of the
Student Council Office is a
flow chart-style diagram of the
new Homewood administration. Penciled in above the top
deans is an extra box containing the word "students." In the

BY PHILLIP SCHMANDT
"The pioneers of a warless
world are the young men who
refuse military service."
—Albert Einstein
Today, two men are standing
behind prison bars who have
committed only one crime: a
crime of conscience. Already
five men have been indicted for
this crime, and more indictments are sure to follow. And
all over the country, 700,000
young men are considered
Felons by our government only
because of their personal

The Drinking Age Dilemma
Maryland's new drinking law, which
raises the legal age for purchasing beer and
wine from 18 to 21, promises to profoundly affect the social life of Hopkins students
as well as the campus social atmosphere. The
new regulations went into effect last July.
Anyone under the age of 18 as of July 1, will
have to wait until his twenty-first birthday
in order to legally purchase beer or wine in
Maryland. Because approximately one-half
of this year's freshman class is affected by
the new law, the consequences of the raised
drinking age are already being felt at
Hopkins.
Freshman orientation was the first campus activity that forced students to grapple
with the new problem. Whereas beer has
been one of the main attractions of previous
orientation parties, this year's activities were
dry. Orientation organizers, a combination
of students and administrators, realized that
serving liquor to only one half of the
freshmen would have severely alienated fifty percent of the class, destroying the principles behind orientation. Furthermore, no
student was willing to sign his name to a liquor license fearing repurcussions in the
event that some underage freshmen were able
to get ahold of liquor. Orientation organizers
were stuck with one option; eliminate beer.
Orientation was the first but certainly not
the last student activity that will be affected
by the new drinking law. Fraternity and class
sponsored parties will invariably run into
similar problems over the next several years.

from campus events will encourage students

entertainment. Regardless of what decision
